text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Subsections 9.6.3.1 through 9.6.3.1.2 reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address Internal Controls (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls memo dated September 14, 2016. Internal Controls are the program manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the:
a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s: mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual
, Pre-Trial Procedures. c. New subsection
is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual
, Pre-Trial Procedures.

IRM Subsection 9.6.3.8(2) updated to reﬂect current National Criminal Investigation Training Academy curriculum which addresses Trial Illustrators as government employees requiring pre-trial notiﬁcation for use as witnesses.

IRM Section 9.6.3.8.1 updated to replace all references to Form 13437A Trial Illustration Request for Services, which is obsolete, with Form 13437 IRS National Forensic Laboratory Request for Services.
IRM Subsection 9.6.3.8.1(1) updated with the current directions from Scheme Development Center concerning the Court Witness program.
IRM Subsection 9.6.3.8.1(9) updated with the current directions from the Trial Graphics and Design Team of the IRS National Forensic Laboratory.

The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

Terms/ Deﬁnition Acronyms AUSA Assistant US Attorney BSA Bank Secrecy Act CI Criminal Investigations CT Criminal Tax DOJ Department of Justice MLEW Money Laundering Expert Witness RAC Resident Agent in Charge SA Special Agent SAC Special Agent in Charge SDC Scheme Development Center TIGTA Treasure Inspector General for Tax Administration

An indictment is a written accusation from a grand jury charging a person or entity with a Federal crime, usually consisting of one or more felony counts. The indictment is presented to the court that impaneled the grand jury by the grand jury foreperson.
9.6 Trial and Court Related Activities
True Bill is signed by the US Attorney it becomes an indictment. An may be found only upon concurrence of

or more jurors. Otherwise, a No True Bill is returned. The court may direct that an indictment be kept secret until the defendant is in custody or has posted bail. In that event, the court clerk seals the indictment and no person may disclose the ﬁnding of the ment except when necessary for the issuance and execution of a warrant or summons, (see Fed. R. Crim. P. R
) Rule

(e) codiﬁes the traditional rule of grand jury secrecy by prohibiting members of the grand jury, attorneys for the government and their authorized assistants, and other grand jury personnel from disclosing matters occurring before the grand jury, except as otherwise authorized by the rule. Grand jury secrecy is vital to the investigative function of the grand jury. As the courts have pointed out, secrecy serves several distinct interests, primarily: a. to encourage witnesses to come forward and testify freely and honestly b. to minimize the risks that prospective defendants will ﬂee or use corrupt means to thwart investigations c. to safeguard the grand jurors themselves and the proceedings from ex- traneous pressures and inﬂuences d. to protect accused persons who are ultimately exonerated from able publicity (

) While the grand jury is in session, the only persons who may be present in grand jury room are attorneys for the government, the witness under tion, a stenographer or operator of a recording device, and interpreters when needed. An indictment may be dismissed upon a showing that an person was present during the proceedings. No person other than the jurors may be present while the grand jury is deliberating or voting, (Fed. R. Crim. R

) Disclosure of matters occurring before the grand jury may be made to ment personnel who are deemed necessary by government attorneys to in the performance of their duty to enforce Federal criminal law. With the consent of the government attorney, SAs may examine documents and that are before the grand jury and inspect its transcripts. In addition, SAs assist in the investigation of criminal tax violations with the approval of the DOJ, Tax Division. (
) Federal Rules of Criminal Procedures Rule

(e) do not impose any obligation of secrecy upon witnesses of a grand jury that would preclude them from dis- cussing their own testimony, although some Federal judicial districts require oath of secrecy. (

) A grand jury is not obliged to grant a request from a prospective defendant to appear before it as a witness. However, DOJ procedures provide that where no burden upon the grand jury or delay of its proceedings is involved, able requests of a prospective defendant to personally testify before the jury are to be given favorable consideration. This may occur only in the event that such witnesses explicitly waive their right against self-incrimination, are represented by counsel or voluntarily and knowingly appear without counsel, and consent to a full examination under oath. (
) After the grand jury’s function has ended, a trial court may order disclosure the grand jury transcript to the defendants if there is a particular need for dis- Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F

The court may direct that an indictment be kept secret until the defendant is in custody or has posted bail. In that event, the court clerk seals the indictment and no person may disclose the ﬁnding of the indict- ment except when necessary for the issuance and execution of a warrant or summons, (see Fed. R. Crim. P. R6(e)).

summons, (see Fed. R. Crim. P. R
(e)). Rule

(e) codiﬁes the traditional rule of grand jury secrecy by prohibiting members of the grand jury, attorneys for the government and their authorized assistants, and other grand jury personnel from disclosing matters occurring before the grand jury, except as otherwise authorized by the rule. Grand jury secrecy is vital to the investigative function of the grand jury. As the courts have pointed out, secrecy serves several distinct interests, primarily:

a. to encourage witnesses to come forward and testify freely and honestly b. to minimize the risks that prospective defendants will ﬂee or use corrupt means to thwart investigations c. to safeguard the grand jurors themselves and the proceedings from ex
traneous pressures and inﬂuences d. to protect accused persons who are ultimately exonerated from unfavor
able publicity
After the grand jury’s function has ended, a trial court may order disclosure of the grand jury transcript to the defendants if there is a particular need for dis-
closure to support an attack upon the indictment, to impeach a witness or refresh recollection, or in a perjury prosecution to inspect their own grand testimony. (

) An information is an accusation in writing against a person named therein some criminal offense (only misdemeanors, unless the defendant expressly waives indictment in open court) and is ﬁled with the court by competent officers, such as the US Attorney, on their oath of office. (

) A complaint is a sworn written statement made before a US Magistrate (magistrate) or, if none is reasonably available, before a state or local officer. It must set forth the essential facts constituting the offense charged should be worded substantially in the statutory language of the offense. It be sworn to positively; the complainant may not merely aver information and belief. It must also be based upon the complainant’s personal knowledge or supported by other proof. In most instances, a SA will author the complaint with assistance from CT Counsel. (

) The ﬁling of a complaint before a magistrate prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations for criminal tax prosecutions will extend the period nine months from the date the complaint is ﬁled, (see
USC

). A complaint must show sufficient probable cause in order to extend the statutory period. should directly indicate that the defendant committed the crime charged and disclose the source of the directly incriminating information (

) Generally, a complaint will be used only in unique circumstances. Typically, charges based on IRS investigations are brought through the grand jury process or by information(s) ﬁled by a US Attorney’s office. A complaint by an IRS SA should only result from an unusual event that requires immediate action, such as may occur during a protection detail, or money dering investigation. A complaint should be reviewed by CT Counsel and approved by the SAC. (

) If there is probable cause to believe that a defendant has committed an offense, the magistrate will issue an arrest warrant or, upon the request of attorney for the government, a court summons in lieu of a warrant requiring R. defendant to appear before the magistrate at a stated time and place to answer the complaint. (If the defendant fails to appear in response to the summons, a warrant could be issued.) As with a complaint, it would be an unusual circumstance for an IRS SA to be involved in obtaining an arrest warrant based on the ﬁling of a complaint. Further, as with any enforcement action, SAC approval is required. (

) More than one warrant or summons may be issued on the same complaint order to facilitate service and return where several defendants are named in the same complaint. Physical delivery of the warrant to the arresting officer not necessary. The officer need not have physical possession of the warrant order to make a lawful arrest, but upon request must show it to the as soon as possible. A warrant for arrest in a criminal investigation is valid anywhere in the United States.

) If there is probable cause to believe that a defendant has committed an offense, the magistrate will issue an arrest warrant or, upon the request of the attorney for the government, a court summons in lieu of a warrant requiring defendant to appear before the magistrate at a stated time and place to answer the complaint. (If the defendant fails to appear in response to the summons, a warrant could be issued.) As with a complaint, it would be an unusual circumstance for an IRS SA to be involved in obtaining an arrest warrant based on the ﬁling of a complaint. Further, as with any enforcement action, SAC approval is required. (

) More than one warrant or summons may be issued on the same complaint in order to facilitate service and return where several defendants are named in the same complaint. Physical delivery of the warrant to the arresting officer is not necessary. The officer need not have physical possession of the warrant order to make a lawful arrest, but upon request must show it to the defendant as soon as possible. A warrant for arrest in a criminal investigation is valid anywhere in the United States.
(05-17-2021) Warrant or Summons Upon Complaint (Fed. Crim. P. R4)
Trial and Court Related (

) At the initial appearance of the arrested person, pursuant to a complaint or warrantless arrest, the judge or magistrate shall set a date for the preliminary (Fed. hearing to determine whether there is probable cause to believe that an R
) offense has been committed and that the arrested person has committed it. The hearing must be held within a reasonable time after the initial but in no event later than: a.

days after the date of the initial appearance if the arrested person is held in custody without any provision for release, is held in custody for failure to meet the conditions of release imposed, or is released from custody only during speciﬁed hours of the day; or b.
days after the initial appearance if the arrested person has been released from custody (
) Usually the magistrate will advise the defendant of the charges, his/her right counsel, and about self incriminating statements. (

) No preliminary hearing is required nor shall an arrested person be released at any time after the initial appearance before the judge or magistrate and to the date ﬁxed for the preliminary hearing, an indictment is returned or, in appropriate investigations, an information is ﬁled in a US court against such person. (

) At the preliminary hearing, the accused may cross-examine adverse and may introduce evidence. The accused is not required to plead at this If the magistrate concludes from the evidence that there is probable cause to believe the accused has committed an offense, or if the accused waives pre- liminary hearing, the magistrate shall forthwith hold the accused to answer in the district court; otherwise, the magistrate shall discharge them. This would not prevent subsequent indictment of the accused on the same charge. (

) As with a complaint, it would be unusual for an IRS SA to be involved in a liminary hearing since the majority of IRS charges will be obtained through indictment or information. CT Counsel should be advised whenever or a sworn statement is required to be taken from an IRS SA. (

) An arraignment consists of calling the defendants before a judge, reading the indictment or information to them or informing them of the charges, and R. on them to enter their plea. The defendants will be given a copy of the indict- R
) ment or information before they are called upon to plead. (

) A defendant may plead not guilty, guilty, or, with the consent of the court, contendere (no contest). The court may refuse to accept a plea of guilty, and shall not accept such plea or a plea of nolo contendere without ﬁrst the defendant personally and determining that the plea is made voluntarily an understanding of the nature of the charge and the consequences of the plea. If a defendant refuses to plead, the court refuses to accept a plea of guilty, or defendant’s corporation fails to appear, the court shall enter a plea not guilty. The court shall not enter a judgment upon a plea of guilty unless it satisﬁed that there is factual basis for the plea. (
) If a not guilty plea is entered, the court proceeds by setting a date for trial. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F
9.6 Trial and Court Related Activities

days after the date of the initial appearance if the arrested person is held in custody without any provision for release, is held in custody for failure to meet the conditions of release imposed, or is released from custody only during speciﬁed hours of the day; or
days after the initial appearance if the arrested person has been released from custody
If a not guilty plea is entered, the court proceeds by setting a date for trial.
Procedures
) If the defendant pleads guilty or nolo contendere at arraignment, the pretrial and trial procedures set forth in Fed. R. Crim. P. R
do not apply and court proceeds to hear the relevant facts prior to imposing sentence. (

) Many courts are informed of the facts by the investigating SA or other sentative of IRS-CI. The role of the SA in this regard is especially important since his/her oral presentation of facts in open court forms the only basis of the offenses charged in the information or indictment (see IRM Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process). (
) A plea of nolo contendere subjects the defendant to the same punishment plea of guilty but does not admit the charges. It cannot be used as an admission in any civil suit for the same act. (

) There are a variety of motions that are usually ﬁled prior to trial. Motions by the defense, such as motions for a change of venue or to disqualify a and Motions judge, are routinely responded to by an attorney for the government with R. Crim. P. R

) involvement from the SA. Responding to other motions, such as those to return seized property or to suppress evidence, may require statements or other involvement by the SA. The primary discussion in this subsection with discovery and Henthorn requests. (
) Rule
affords pre-trial opportunities for the government and the defense examine evidence in the opposing party’s possession, custody, or control. (Fed. R. Crim. (
) The government or a defendant can, by using a subpoena duces tecum, R
) compel the pre-trial production of evidentiary material per Fed. R. Crim. P. R
) Special agents should make certain that any request for such information is authorized for disclosure under
USC
The SA should consult with ﬁeld office CT Counsel and the attorney for the government for guidance. (

) The Supreme Court’s rulings in Brady and Giglio impose an affirmative duty AUSAs to disclose readily obtainable exculpatory information, including im- Requests peachment information, regardless of whether a defense motion has been ﬁled. Henthorn is a more recent Ninth Circuit decision in the Giglio line and extends the Giglio principle to discovery. Henthorn searches for personnel records are made in response to a defense motion for discovery. (

) Impeachment material is generally that which calls into question a witness’ honesty, integrity, or impartiality, but it can extend to anything which effects credibility and veracity of the testimony offered. Depending upon the nature the testimony, it can also include material that calls into question ability, thoroughness, attention to detail, visual or auditory acuity, sobriety, reputation in the community, etc. (

) If impeachment material is serious enough, it could result in the attorney for the government refusing to allow a SA or other IRS employee to testify. US Attorneys’ offices will track all impeachment material provided to courts, defense counsel, or disclosed to the public. Some IRS employees could possibly encounter additional barriers to testifying in some types of tions.
) If the defendant pleads guilty or nolo contendere at arraignment, the pretrial and trial procedures set forth in Fed. R. Crim. P. R
do not apply and the court proceeds to hear the relevant facts prior to imposing sentence. (

) Many courts are informed of the facts by the investigating SA or other repre- sentative of IRS-CI. The role of the SA in this regard is especially important since his/her oral presentation of facts in open court forms the only basis of the offenses charged in the information or indictment (see IRM
, Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process). (
) A plea of nolo contendere subjects the defendant to the same punishment as plea of guilty but does not admit the charges. It cannot be used as an admission in any civil suit for the same act. (

) There are a variety of motions that are usually ﬁled prior to trial. Motions ﬁled by the defense, such as motions for a change of venue or to disqualify a judge, are routinely responded to by an attorney for the government with little involvement from the SA. Responding to other motions, such as those to return seized property or to suppress evidence, may require statements or other involvement by the SA. The primary discussion in this subsection deals with discovery and Henthorn requests. (
) Rule
affords pre-trial opportunities for the government and the defense to

Motions ﬁled by the defense, such as motions for a change of venue or to disqualify a judge, are routinely responded to by an attorney for the government with little involvement from the SA. Responding to other motions, such as those to return seized property or to suppress evidence, may require statements or other involvement by the SA. The primary discussion in this subsection deals with discovery and Henthorn requests.
The Supreme Court’s rulings in Brady and Giglio impose an affirmative duty AUSAs to disclose readily obtainable exculpatory information, including im

peachment information, regardless of whether a defense motion has been ﬁled. Henthorn is a more recent Ninth Circuit decision in the Giglio line and extends the Giglio principle to discovery. Henthorn searches for personnel records are made in response to a defense motion for discovery.

Impeachment material is generally that which calls into question a witness’ honesty, integrity, or impartiality, but it can extend to anything which effects credibility and veracity of the testimony offered. Depending upon the nature of the testimony, it can also include material that calls into question competence, ability, thoroughness, attention to detail, visual or auditory acuity, sobriety,
Trial and Court Related (
) Treasury Order

obligates each employee witness or affiant to inform the attorney for the government of such information. Usually, the more the prosecutor knows about any potential impeachment material, the better will be able to overcome it. (

) Henthorn requests are forwarded from the attorney for the government to SAC. The SAC or his/her designee (at least two levels above the employee witness) is the responsible official for determining the materiality of contained in the personnel ﬁle of IRS “ﬁeld level” employees. The SAC may also delegate the review to the ﬁeld office CT Counsel. (

) Upon receiving a Henthorn request, the SAC or his/her designee shall: a. Notify the management of the other operating division in which the employee-witness works and request the employee’s various ﬁles as shown below; and b. Examine the employee’s personnel ﬁles for evidence affecting witness credibility or other exculpatory and/or impeachment material subject to discovery. If any uncertainty exists, the attorney for the government CT Counsel should be contacted for guidance. (

) The SAC or his/her designee will then write a letter to the attorney for the ernment (see Henthorn Reply template in CI Uniﬁed Checklist) and include declaration that the personnel ﬁles have been reviewed. The letter will one of the following statements: a. No evidence of perjurious conduct or dishonesty, nor anything that be considered as exculpatory or impeachment materials subject to discovery was detected. b. The attached information, obtained from the ﬁles listed, may constitute material subject to discovery. Please examine this information to make determination. (

) If the Henthorn request received by the SAC concerns a CT Counsel employee whose post of duty is in the ﬁeld office, notiﬁcation should be sent the Area Counsel. For a CT Counsel employee whose post of duty is in quarters, notiﬁcation should be sent to the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax). (

) The following eight categories of ﬁles are relevant to a Henthorn request, must be obtained and examined: a. Official Personnel Files (OPFs) b. Employee Performance ﬁles c. Drop ﬁles d. **Employee Investigative ﬁles e. Disciplinary and Adverse Action Investigation ﬁles f. Grievance ﬁles g. Merit System Protection Board ﬁles h. Equal Employment Opportunity ﬁles Note: ** Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration should be contacted concerning investigative ﬁles of grade

employees and executives. Because of the privacy interests of the employee-witness, TIGTA has expressed reservations regarding the release of certain Internal Security vestigative ﬁles or reports of investigation to anyone in the supervisory of the employee-witness. Therefore, TIGTA has the option of releasing Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F
9.6 Trial and Court Related Activities
discovery was detected. b. The attached information, obtained from the ﬁles listed, may constitute material subject to discovery. Please examine this information to make a determination. (

) If the Henthorn request received by the SAC concerns a CT Counsel employee whose post of duty is in the ﬁeld office, notiﬁcation should be sent to the Area Counsel. For a CT Counsel employee whose post of duty is in Head- quarters, notiﬁcation should be sent to the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax). (

) The following eight categories of ﬁles are relevant to a Henthorn request, and must be obtained and examined: a. Official Personnel Files (OPFs) b. Employee Performance ﬁles c. Drop ﬁles d. **Employee Investigative ﬁles e. Disciplinary and Adverse Action Investigation ﬁles f. Grievance ﬁles g. Merit System Protection Board ﬁles h. Equal Employment Opportunity ﬁles Note: ** Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration should be contacted concerning investigative ﬁles of grade

employees and executives. Because of the privacy interests of the employee-witness, TIGTA has expressed reservations regarding the release of certain Internal Security in- vestigative ﬁles or reports of investigation to anyone in the supervisory chain of the employee-witness. Therefore, TIGTA has the option of releasing such
ﬁles directly to the attorney for the government, or to Area Counsel, who examine such ﬁles separately and advise the attorney for the government to their contents. (
) The SAC must comply with the Privacy Act Accounting of Disclosure ments set forth at
USC
a(c). See IRM
, Disclosure of Official Information, for additional information. (
) If return information is to be disclosed, the material should be submitted in camera for the court to make a Brady relevance determination giving due sideration to the statutory proscriptions in
USC
To the extent taxpayer identifying information should be redacted. (

) All information disclosed must be accompanied by the following statement: information concerning (name of employee-witness) was obtained from IRS personnel and/or investigative ﬁles. The information is being provided to for official use only and remains the property of the IRS. Any further tion of this information should be coordinated with (name of CT Counsel) to disclosure. Once the need for this information has expired, the should be returned or destroyed. (
) The information should be hand-delivered to the attorney for the this is not possible, the information should be transmitted in a double with the marking TO BE OPENED BY ADDRESSEE ONLY. (
) The SA should complete all administrative duties, as detailed below, as far advance of the trial as possible. (

) The SA should notify government employees who will be witnesses, giving them as much advance notice as possible. These may include: a. SDC or processing center witness, b. Summary or expert witness, c. Forensic Laboratory witness, and/or d. Trial Illustrators (

) The SA should secure documents in the custody and control of the IRS that will be used at trial. These include: a. All available original income tax returns. The Disclosure Office should contacted for procedures to obtain certiﬁed copies of the original tax returns. b. Other original documents and correspondence ﬁled by the defendant the IRS. c. Current certiﬁed transcripts of accounts, certiﬁcates of assessments payments, or certiﬁcates of lack of record. (
) The SA should contact Fi
EN to request and obtain certiﬁed BSA records that will be used at trial. These records include Currency Transaction Suspicious Activity Reports, and Forms
The procedures for and obtaining certiﬁed BSA records from Fi
EN can be found in CASE munities of Practice (C
) The SA should arrange to have any prisoners available for trial if they are be used as witnesses.

Other original documents and correspondence ﬁled by the defendant the IRS. c. Current certiﬁed transcripts of accounts, certiﬁcates of assessments and payments, or certiﬁcates of lack of record. Other original documents and correspondence ﬁled by the defendant with the IRS. Current certiﬁed transcripts of accounts, certiﬁcates of assessments and payments, or certiﬁcates of lack of record.
Trial and Court Related (
) The SA should review all stipulations for accuracy. (

) The request for an SDC witness should be made by memorandum from the SSA to the Director, Refund Crimes. The request should include the a. trial date b. location c. social security or employer identiﬁcation number d. CIMIS case number and Pacer Docket number e. personal and business addresses f. the scheduled date and place of the trial g. date witness needed h. date of indictment i. nature of testimony required j. name and telephone number of the attorney for the government who is handling the investigation k. IRS documents and records to be entered into evidence l. volume of certiﬁed documents needed m. brief synopsis of case n. special agent’s name and telephone number (
) In a tax trial, the government often uses the revenue agent as an expert witness to establish the computations of deﬁciencies as set forth in the ment or information. (

) In a money laundering trial, the government may utilize a SA trained as a MLEW to explain ﬁnancial transactions and establish the computation of laundered funds, as set forth in the indictment or information. (

) An expert witness is a person qualiﬁed by knowledge, skill, experience, or education to provide testimony that may assist the jury in understanding evidence or determining a fact in issue (see Federal Rules of Evidence The trial judge determines whether his/her qualiﬁcations are sufficient. (

) In tax investigations, expert witnesses may be used to testify concerning various matters such as handwriting comparison, accounting and procedures, methods of operating a lottery, and computation of income tax liability. (

) In money laundering and BSA investigations, expert witnesses may be testify concerning money laundering transactions, the methods of money dering, statutes, and computation of laundered funds. A request for a should be made in writing to the MLEW cadre for IRS CI and should the following: a. CIMIS investigation number b. type of money laundering investigation c. short synopsis of investigation d. estimated length of trial e. location of trial f. trial preparation dates g. anticipated trial date h. copy of indictment (
) A request for a witness from the Forensic Lab should be made in writing include the following:
The request for an SDC witness should be made by memorandum from the SSA to the Director, Refund Crimes. The request should include the following:
A request for a witness from the Forensic Lab should be made in writing and include the following:

a. defendant’s name b. the investigation number c. the SA’s name and telephone number d. the government attorney’s name and telephone number e. the anticipated trial date f. a brief synopsis of the investigation g. a return mailing address (
) Requests for witnesses from the Forensic Lab, other than trial illustrators, should be sent to: Criminal Investigation National Forensic Laboratory
W. Van Buren, Suite
Chicago, IL
Tel: (
Fax: (
) Requests for the services of the trial illustrator (who reports to the Director, Forensic Lab) should be submitted on IRS National Forensic Laboratory Request for Services,
days prior to the anticipated trial. The Form can be e-mailed or mailed directly to: Manager, Trial Graphics and Design Team
Turfway Rd. Suite
Florence, KY
Tel: (
Fax: (
) The Trial Illustrator Unit can provide information for use in cost of computations, including travel costs, materials and supplies, illustrator hour costs, and shipping costs. See IRM
, Investigative Services, for additional information. (

) The government exhibit list is used during trial to keep track of exhibits have been entered into evidence. Copies are provided to the court, counsel, and the summary or expert witness. The exhibits should be listed List numbered in the order of anticipated introduction into evidence. All be introduced at trial is listed, including documents that will be admitted through stipulation. (

) The following information should be listed for each exhibit: a. exhibit number b. description of the document c. two spaces, one to indicate when the document was offered into evidence and the other to show if it was admitted d. the relevance of the document, identiﬁcation of the witness who will introducing the document, and other comments may also be included the government’s copy of the exhibit list (
) The attorney for the government should be consulted for his/her particular erences.
Trial and Court Related (

) The SA will frequently be asked to assist in the preparation of a trial brief trial book. A sheet should be prepared for each witness showing: a. full name, address, and telephone number b. business or occupation, business telephone number, and employer c. a summary of expected testimony d. a list and description of documents, if any, which the witnesses will produce or identify e. the location of the evidence if not in the custody of the witness or government f. comments and data which reﬂect the witness’ reliability or credibility, including criminal record and relationship to the defendant or other witnesses g. a list of all documents such as question and answer statements, vits, or memoranda of interviews obtained from the witness or by the SA (

) The witness sheets may be placed in a loose-leaf notebook in the order witnesses are expected to testify. If many witnesses are involved, it is for reference purposes to assign each a number and prepare a list of witnesses arranged and numbered in the same order as the witness (

) Usually a folder should be prepared for each witness, bearing the witness’ name and number. The folder should contain: a. a copy of the witness sheet b. a copy of the subpoena c. documents, such as memoranda, affidavits, or question and answer statements relating to the witness d. documents obtained from the witness prior to trial that will be offered evidence and copies to be substituted when originals are withdrawn e. charts, schedules, graphs, photographs, and other visual aids or evidence to be introduced by the witness (

) In anticipation of trial, the attorney for the government may direct the SA make certain that all government witnesses to be called at trial can be are prepared to testify, and, if necessary, are provided protection (see IRM
, Other Investigations). Trial subpoenas are usually served on all witnesses who are not Federal employees. (
) The government attorney will request the SA’s assistance in the and service of subpoenas for witnesses to appear. The SA should review subpoena for accuracy and content. (

) Witnesses should be requested to appear in court in advance of testifying purposes of reviewing their testimony and ascertaining whether the documentary evidence is available. Witnesses should be given the possible notice prior to their appearance so that the necessary travel ments can be made. (
) The SA should inform the attorney for the government as soon as any circumstances that may affect the timely appearance of a witness or any difficulty in locating or serving a witness.
The SA will frequently be asked to assist in the preparation of a trial brief or trial book. A sheet should be prepared for each witness showing:

full name, address, and telephone number business or occupation, business telephone number, and employer a summary of expected testimony a list and description of documents, if any, which the witnesses will produce or identify the location of the evidence if not in the custody of the witness or the government comments and data which reﬂect the witness’ reliability or credibility, including criminal record and relationship to the defendant or other witnesses a list of all documents such as question and answer statements, vits, or memoranda of interviews obtained from the witness or by the SA

In anticipation of trial, the attorney for the government may direct the SA to make certain that all government witnesses to be called at trial can be located, are prepared to testify, and, if necessary, are provided protection (see IRM 9.5.11, Other Investigations). Trial subpoenas are usually served on all
page (
) In most instances, collateral requests should be used to serve subpoenas on witnesses located outside the ﬁeld office. (

) The SA should maintain a list of all subpoenas to be served, the date each was received, the date each was served, and the date each was returned to the court. A copy of the served subpoena should be maintained in the folder. (

) The SA should only re-interview witnesses with the approval of the attorney the government. The SA should discuss with the attorney for the government of what topics should be covered in the interviews. Often the attorney for the ernment will participate in the interview. Some of the areas that the attorney may suggest include whether the witness has brought subpoenaed or physical evidence, can recall his/her previous statements (it may be advisable for the witness to read transcripts of prior statements), and can identify the defendant and time and place of any pertinent event. The SA should report any anticipated difficulties with the witnesses to the attorney for the government. (

) The attorney for the government will normally require the assistance of the in complying with a court order for discovery. After the attorney for the ment and the SA have determined which documents and statements are to provided to defense counsel, the SA should make arrangements to have the material duplicated. If the records are voluminous and the attorney for the ernment agrees, it may be advisable to invite defense counsel to the office where the records are located to review them. (
) The SA should prepare an inventory for defense counsel that includes a de- scription of the documents and the date provided. A copy should be given to the attorney for the government. (

) The SA should inform the attorney for the government of any evidence that should be considered under the Brady doctrine. Under the Brady doctrine, defense is entitled to the production of any exculpatory evidence in the pos- session of the government. (

) As soon as possible after the indictment has been returned or the has been ﬁled, the SA should make arrangements to meet with the attorney the government handling the investigation for a pretrial conference. (

) The discussion should include the following: a. any discussions the attorney for the government has had with the defendant or defense counsel regarding motions ﬁled, defenses presented, and plea offerings b. any recent changes affecting government witnesses c. the anticipated direction of the trial, including the order of witnesses to called and evidence to be introduced d. the use of protected witnesses and informants as government e. the SA’s testimony to be given at trial f. the evidence the parties will agree to have entered by stipulation g. illustrations, charts, graphs, or photographs to be used h. the SA’s duties and responsibilities in assisting the attorney for the ernment to prepare for the trial Internal Revenue Manual
